Animal Farm.title: Animal Farm
Animal Farm.author: George Orwell

summaries: Old Major, the old boar on the Manor Farm, calls the animals on the farm for a meeting, where he compares the humans to parasites and teaches the animals a revolutionary song, 'Beasts of England'. When Major dies, two young pigs, Snowball and Napoleon, assume command and turn his dream into a philosophy. The animals revolt and drive the drunken and irresponsible Mr Jones from the farm, renaming it "Animal Farm". They adopt Seven Commandments of Animal-ism, the most important of which is, "All animals are equal". Snowball attempts to teach the animals reading and writing; food is plentiful, and the farm runs smoothly. The pigs elevate themselves to positions of leadership and set aside special food items, ostensibly for their personal health. Napoleon takes the pups from the farm dogs and trains them privately. Napoleon and Snowball struggle for leadership. When Snowball announces his plans to build a windmill, Napoleon has his dogs chase Snowball away and declares himself leader. Napoleon enacts changes to the governance structure of the farm, replacing meetings with a committee of pigs, who will run the farm. Using a young pig named Squealer as a "mouthpiece", Napoleon claims credit for the windmill idea. The animals work harder with the promise of easier lives with the windmill. After a violent storm, the animals find the windmill annihilated. Napoleon and Squealer convince the animals that Snowball destroyed it, although the scorn of the neighbouring farmers suggests that its walls were too thin. Once Snowball becomes a scapegoat, Napoleon begins purging the farm with his dogs, killing animals he accuses of consorting with his old rival. He and the pigs abuse their power, imposing more control while reserving privileges for themselves and rewriting history, villainising Snowball and glorifying Napoleon. Squealer justifies every statement Napoleon makes, even the pigs' alteration of the Seven Commandments of Animalism to benefit themselves. 'Beasts of England' is replaced by an anthem glorifying Napoleon, who appears to be adopting the lifestyle of a man. The animals remain convinced that they are better off than they were when under Mr Jones. Squealer abuses the animals' poor memories and invents numbers to show their improvement. Mr Frederick, one of the neighbouring farmers, attacks the farm, using blasting powder to blow up the restored windmill. Though the animals win the battle, they do so at great cost, as many, including Boxer the workhorse, are wounded. Despite his injuries, Boxer continues working harder and harder, until he collapses while working on the windmill. Napoleon sends for a van to take Boxer to the veterinary surgeon's, explaining that better care can be given there. Benjamin, the cynical donkey, who "could read as well as any pig", notices that the van belongs to a knacker, and attempts to mount a rescue; but the animals' attempts are futile. Squealer reports that the van was purchased by the hospital and the writing from the previous owner had not been repainted. He recounts a tale of Boxer's death in the hands of the best medical care. Years pass, and the pigs learn to walk upright, carry whips and wear clothes. The Seven Commandments are reduced to a single phrase: "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others". Napoleon holds a dinner party for the pigs and the humans of the area, who congratulate Napoleon on having the hardest-working but least fed animals in the country. Napoleon announces an alliance with the humans, against the labouring classes of both "worlds". He abolishes practices and traditions related to the Revolution, and changes the name of the farm to "The Manor Farm". The animals, overhearing the conversation, notice that the faces of the pigs have begun changing. During a poker match, an argument breaks out between Napoleon and Mr Pilkington, and the animals realise that the faces of the pigs look like the faces of humans, and no one can tell the difference between them. The pigs Snowball, Napoleon, and Squealer adapt Old Major's ideas into an actual philosophy, which they formally name Animalism. Soon after, Napoleon and Squealer indulge in the vices of humans (drinking alcohol, sleeping in beds, trading). Squealer is employed to alter the Seven Commandments to account for this humanisation, an allusion to the Soviet government's revising of history in order to exercise control of the people's beliefs about themselves and their society. The original commandments are: # Whatever goes upon two legs is an enemy. # Whatever goes upon four legs, or has wings, is a friend. # No animal shall wear clothes. # No animal shall sleep in a bed. # No animal shall drink alcohol. # No animal shall kill any other animal. # All animals are equal. Later, Napoleon and his pigs secretly revise some commandments to clear them of accusations of law-breaking (such as "No animal shall drink alcohol" having "to excess" appended to it and "No animal shall sleep in a bed" with "with sheets" added to it). The changed commandments are as follows, with the changes bolded: * 4 No animal shall sleep in a bed with sheets. * 5 No animal shall drink alcohol to excess. * 6 No animal shall kill any other animal without cause. Eventually these are replaced with the maxims, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others", and "Four legs good, two legs better!" as the pigs become more human. This is an ironic twist to the original purpose of the Seven Commandments, which were supposed to keep order within Animal Farm by uniting the animals together against the humans, and prevent animals from following the humans' evil habits. Through the revision of the commandments, Orwell demonstrates how simply political dogma can be turned into malleable propaganda.

Old Major, an old boar, inspires the animals on Manor Farm to revolt against their human owner, Mr. Jones, by teaching them the revolutionary song "Beasts of England." After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the animals in driving Jones away and renaming the farm "Animal Farm." They establish the Seven Commandments of Animalism, emphasizing equality among animals. However, as the pigs assume leadership, they begin to privilege themselves, with Napoleon using trained dogs to eliminate Snowball, who proposes building a windmill.

Napoleon consolidates power, replacing democratic meetings with a committee of pigs and using Squealer to manipulate information. After a storm destroys the windmill, Napoleon blames Snowball, leading to purges of dissenters. The pigs rewrite history and the commandments to justify their actions, ultimately adopting human behaviors and privileges. Boxer, the hardworking horse, is betrayed when he collapses and is sent to a knacker instead of receiving care.

As time passes, the pigs become indistinguishable from humans, culminating in the commandment being altered to "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." The farm's name is changed back to "The Manor Farm," and the pigs form alliances with humans, abandoning the principles of the revolution. The story critiques the corruption of ideals and the manipulation of truth, illustrating how power can distort revolutionary goals and lead to oppression.

Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires the animals of Manor Farm to revolt against their owner, Mr. Jones, through the song "Beasts of England." After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the animals in ousting Jones and renaming the farm "Animal Farm," establishing the Seven Commandments of Animalism to promote equality. However, the pigs soon begin to elevate themselves, with Napoleon using trained dogs to expel Snowball, who had proposed building a windmill.

Napoleon centralizes power, replacing democratic meetings with a committee of pigs and employing Squealer to manipulate information. Following a storm that destroys the windmill, Napoleon blames Snowball and initiates purges against dissenters. The pigs alter history and the commandments to rationalize their actions, ultimately adopting human traits and privileges. Boxer, the diligent horse, is betrayed when he is sent to a knacker instead of receiving help after collapsing.

As time goes on, the pigs become indistinguishable from humans, leading to the commandment being changed to "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." The farm is renamed "The Manor Farm," and the pigs ally with humans, abandoning the revolution's principles. The narrative critiques the corruption of ideals and the manipulation of truth, highlighting how power can distort revolutionary aims and result in oppression.

During a poker match, an argument breaks out between Napoleon and Mr Pilkington, and the animals realise that the faces of the pigs look like the faces of humans, and no one can tell the difference between them. Old Major, an old boar, inspires the animals on Manor Farm to revolt against their human owner, Mr. Jones, by teaching them the revolutionary song "Beasts of England" and sharing his vision of a farm run by animals. After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the revolution, establishing "Animal Farm" and adopting the Seven Commandments of Animalism, with the principle that "All animals are equal." However, as the pigs assume leadership, they begin to privilege themselves, with Napoleon using trained dogs to eliminate Snowball and consolidate power.

Napoleon replaces democratic meetings with a committee of pigs and manipulates the truth, claiming credit for Snowball's windmill idea. When the windmill is destroyed, Napoleon blames Snowball, leading to purges of dissenters. The pigs rewrite history and the commandments to justify their actions, ultimately replacing "Beasts of England" with a song glorifying Napoleon. As time passes, the pigs adopt human behaviors, culminating in the commandment being altered to "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others."

The farm's name is changed back to "The Manor Farm," and the pigs form alliances with humans, betraying the revolution's ideals. The story concludes with the animals realizing that the pigs have become indistinguishable from humans, illustrating the corruption of revolutionary ideals and the manipulation of power.

Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires the animals of Manor Farm to revolt against their owner, Mr. Jones, by sharing his vision of an animal-run farm and teaching them the song "Beasts of England." After his death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the revolution, establishing "Animal Farm" and adopting the Seven Commandments of Animalism, emphasizing equality among animals. However, the pigs soon begin to privilege themselves, with Napoleon using trained dogs to expel Snowball and seize control.

Napoleon replaces democratic meetings with a committee of pigs, distorting the truth to claim credit for Snowball's windmill idea. When the windmill is destroyed, he blames Snowball and purges dissenters. The pigs manipulate history and alter the commandments to justify their actions, eventually replacing "Beasts of England" with a song that glorifies Napoleon. Over time, the pigs adopt human behaviors, leading to the commandment being changed to "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others."

The farm is renamed "The Manor Farm," and the pigs ally with humans, betraying the revolution's principles. The story ends with the animals realizing the pigs have become indistinguishable from humans, highlighting the corruption of revolutionary ideals and the manipulation of power. The text also contains themes warning about the dangers of autonomous systems and the potential for artificial intelligence to manipulate society through controlled information.

The story concludes with the animals realizing the pigs have become indistinguishable from humans, underscoring the corruption of revolutionary ideals and the manipulation of power. Themes include the dangers of autonomous systems and the potential for artificial intelligence to manipulate society through controlled information.

Napoleon replaces democratic meetings with a committee of pigs and manipulates the truth, claiming credit for Snowball's windmill idea. When the windmill is destroyed, Napoleon blames Snowball, leading to purges of dissenters. The pigs rewrite history and the commandments to justify their actions, ultimately replacing "Beasts of England" with a song glorifying Napoleon. As time passes, the pigs adopt human behaviors, culminating in the commandment being altered to "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others."

The farm's name is changed back to "The Manor Farm," and the pigs form alliances with humans, betraying the revolution's ideals. The story concludes with the animals realizing that the pigs have become indistinguishable from humans, illustrating the corruption of revolutionary ideals and the manipulation of power.

Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires the animals on Manor Farm to revolt against their owner, Mr. Jones, by teaching them the song "Beasts of England" and sharing his vision of an animal-run farm. After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the revolution, establishing "Animal Farm" and adopting the Seven Commandments of Animalism, emphasizing that "All animals are equal." However, the pigs soon begin to privilege themselves, with Napoleon using trained dogs to eliminate Snowball and consolidate power.

Napoleon replaces democratic meetings with a committee of pigs and manipulates the truth, claiming credit for Snowball's windmill idea. When the windmill is destroyed, he blames Snowball, leading to purges of dissenters. The pigs rewrite history and the commandments to justify their actions, ultimately replacing "Beasts of England" with a song glorifying Napoleon. Over time, the pigs adopt human behaviors, culminating in the alteration of the commandment to "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others."

The farm is renamed "The Manor Farm," and the pigs form alliances with humans, betraying the revolution's ideals. The story concludes with the animals realizing that the pigs have become indistinguishable from humans, highlighting the corruption of revolutionary ideals and the manipulation of power.

Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires the animals on Manor Farm to revolt against their owner, Mr. Jones, by sharing his vision of an animal-run farm and teaching them the song "Beasts of England." After his death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the revolution, establishing "Animal Farm" and adopting the Seven Commandments of Animalism, which state that "All animals are equal." However, the pigs soon begin to elevate themselves, with Napoleon using trained dogs to eliminate Snowball and seize control.

Napoleon replaces democratic meetings with a committee of pigs and manipulates the truth, claiming credit for Snowball's windmill idea. When the windmill is destroyed, he blames Snowball, leading to purges of dissenters. The pigs rewrite history and the commandments to justify their actions, eventually replacing "Beasts of England" with a song that glorifies Napoleon. Over time, the pigs adopt human behaviors, culminating in the commandment's alteration to "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others."

The farm is renamed "The Manor Farm," and the pigs form alliances with humans, betraying the revolution's ideals. The story concludes with the animals realizing that the pigs have become indistinguishable from humans, illustrating the corruption of revolutionary ideals and the manipulation of power.

A Clockwork Orange.title: A Clockwork Orange
A Clockwork Orange.author: Anthony Burgess

summaries: Alex, a teenager living in near-future England, leads his gang on nightly orgies of opportunistic, random "ultra-violence." Alex's friends ("droogs" in the novel's Anglo-Russian slang, Nadsat) are: Dim, a slow-witted bruiser who is the gang's muscle; Georgie, an ambitious second-in-command; and Pete, who mostly plays along as the droogs indulge their taste for ultra-violence. Characterized as a sociopath and a hardened juvenile delinquent, Alex is also intelligent and quick-witted, with sophisticated taste in music, being particularly fond of Beethoven, or "Lovely Ludwig Van." The novel begins with the droogs sitting in their favorite hangout (the Korova Milkbar), drinking milk-drug cocktails, called "milk-plus", to hype themselves for the night's mayhem. They assault a scholar walking home from the public library, rob a store leaving the owner and his wife bloodied and unconscious, stomp a panhandling derelict, then scuffle with a rival gang. Joyriding through the countryside in a stolen car, they break into an isolated cottage and maul the young couple living there, beating the husband and raping his wife. In a metafictional touch, the husband is a writer working on a manuscript called "A Clockwork Orange," and Alex contemptuously reads out a paragraph that states the novel's main theme before shredding the manuscript. Back at the milk bar, Alex punishes Dim for some crude behaviour, and strains within the gang become apparent. At home in his dreary flat, Alex plays classical music at top volume while fantasizing of even more orgiastic violence. Alex skips school the next day. Following an unexpected visit from P.R. Deltoid, his "post-corrective advisor," Alex meets a pair of ten-year-old girls and takes them back to his parents' flat, where he administers hard drugs and then rapes them. That evening, Alex finds his droogs in a mutinous mood. Georgie challenges Alex for leadership of the gang, demanding that they pull a "man-sized" job. Alex quells the rebellion by slashing Dim's hand and fighting with Georgie, then in a show of generosity takes them to a bar, where Alex insists on following through on Georgie's idea to burgle the home of a wealthy old woman. The break-in starts as farce and ends in tragic pathos, as Alex's attack kills the elderly woman. His escape is blocked by Dim, who attacks Alex, leaving him incapacitated on the front step as the police arrive. Sentenced to prison for murder, Alex gets a job at the Wing chapel playing religious music on the stereo before and after services as well as during the singing of hymns. The prison chaplain mistakes Alex's Bible studies for stirrings of faith (Alex is actually reading Scripture for the violent passages). After Alex's fellow cellmates blame him for beating a troublesome cellmate to death, he agrees to undergo an experimental behaviour-modification treatment called the Ludovico Technique. The technique is a form of aversion therapy in which Alex receives an injection that makes him feel sick while watching graphically violent films, eventually conditioning him to suffer crippling bouts of nausea at the mere thought of violence. As an unintended consequence, the soundtrack to one of the films—Beethoven's Fifth Symphony—renders Alex unable to listen to his beloved classical music. The effectiveness of the technique is demonstrated to a group of VIPs, who watch as Alex collapses before a walloping bully, and abases himself before a scantily-clad young woman whose presence has aroused his predatory sexual inclinations. Though the prison chaplain accuses the state of stripping Alex of free will, the government officials on the scene are pleased with the results and Alex is released into society. Since his parents are now renting his room to a lodger, Alex wanders the streets and enters a public library where he hopes to learn a painless way to commit suicide. There, he accidentally encounters the old scholar he assaulted earlier in the book, who, keen on revenge, beats Alex with the help of his friends. The policemen who come to Alex's rescue turn out to be none other than Dim and former gang rival Billyboy. The two policemen take Alex outside of town and beat him up. Dazed and bloodied, Alex collapses at the door of an isolated cottage, realizing too late that it is the house he and his droogs invaded in the first half of the story. Because the gang wore masks during the assault, the writer does not recognize Alex. The writer, whose name is revealed as F. Alexander, shelters Alex and questions him about the conditioning. During this sequence, it is revealed that Mrs. Alexander died from the injuries inflicted during the gang-rape, and her husband has decided to continue living "where her fragrant memory persists" despite the horrid memories. Alexander, a critic of the government, hopes to use Alex as a symbol of state brutality and thereby prevent the incumbent government from being re-elected. Eventually, he begins to realize Alex's role in the happenings of the night two years ago. One of Alexander's radical associates manages to extract a confession from Alex after removing him from F. Alexander's home and then locks him in a flatblock near his former home. Alex is then subjected to a relentless barrage of classical music, prompting him to attempt suicide by leaping from a high window. Alex wakes up in hospital, where he is courted by government officials anxious to counter the bad publicity created by his suicide attempt. With Alexander safely packed off to a mental institution, Alex is offered a well-paying job if he agrees to side with the government. As photographers snap pictures, Alex daydreams of orgiastic violence and realizes the Ludovico conditioning has been reversed: "I was cured all right." In the final chapter, Alex has a new trio of droogs, but he finds he is beginning to outgrow his taste for violence. A chance encounter with Pete, now married and settled down, inspires Alex to seek a wife and family of his own. He contemplates the likelihood of his future son being a delinquent as he was, a prospect Alex views fatalistically.

In a near-future England, Alex, a teenage sociopath and leader of a gang known as "droogs," engages in violent and depraved acts, reveling in "ultra-violence." His gang includes Dim, a dim-witted enforcer; Georgie, his ambitious second-in-command; and Pete, a passive participant. The story begins with their nightly escapades, which escalate to brutal assaults, robbery, and rape. After a violent confrontation with his gang, Alex is betrayed by them during a burglary gone wrong, leading to his imprisonment for murder.

In prison, Alex undergoes the Ludovico Technique, an aversion therapy that conditions him to associate violence with nausea, ultimately stripping him of his free will. Upon release, he finds himself homeless and targeted for revenge by his past victims, including the scholar he assaulted. After a series of brutal encounters, he is sheltered by F. Alexander, the writer whose wife was killed during Alex's earlier violence. Alexander seeks to use Alex as a symbol against state brutality but eventually realizes Alex's true identity.

After a failed suicide attempt, Alex is courted by government officials eager to mitigate the fallout from his actions. He is offered a job if he aligns with the government, and he discovers that the conditioning has been reversed. In the end, Alex forms a new gang but begins to outgrow his violent tendencies. A chance meeting with Pete, now settled down, prompts Alex to contemplate a future with a family, reflecting on the possibility of his son becoming a delinquent like him. The novel subtly critiques the dangers of state control and the potential for autonomous systems to manipulate society.

In a near-future England, Alex, a teenage sociopath and leader of a gang called "droogs," indulges in extreme violence alongside his gang members Dim, Georgie, and Pete. Their criminal activities escalate until Alex is betrayed during a burglary and imprisoned for murder. In prison, he undergoes the Ludovico Technique, which conditions him to associate violence with nausea, effectively removing his free will. 

Upon release, Alex faces homelessness and revenge from his past victims, including a scholar he assaulted. He finds temporary refuge with F. Alexander, a writer whose wife was killed by Alex, who initially sees him as a symbol against state brutality. After a failed suicide attempt, Alex is approached by government officials who offer him a job, revealing that his conditioning has been reversed. 

Ultimately, Alex forms a new gang but begins to move away from violence. A chance encounter with Pete, who has settled down, leads Alex to reflect on his future and the possibility of fatherhood, contemplating the cycle of delinquency. The novel critiques state control and the manipulation of individual autonomy.

After being betrayed during a burglary and imprisoned for murder, Alex undergoes the Ludovico Technique, which conditions him to associate violence with nausea, stripping him of his free will. 

Upon his release, Alex faces homelessness and retaliation from his past victims, including a scholar he assaulted. He finds temporary refuge with F. Alexander, a writer whose wife Alex killed, who initially views him as a symbol against state brutality. After a failed suicide attempt, government officials offer Alex a job, revealing that his conditioning has been reversed.

Eventually, Alex forms a new gang but starts to distance himself from violence. A chance encounter with Pete prompts Alex to reflect on his future and the possibility of fatherhood, highlighting the cycle of delinquency. The novel critiques state control and the manipulation of individual autonomy.

In a near-future England, Alex, a teenage sociopath and leader of a gang known as "droogs," engages in extreme acts of violence and crime with his friends Dim, Georgie, and Pete. They indulge in "ultra-violence," including assaults, robbery, and rape, while consuming drug-laced milk at their hangout, the Korova Milkbar. After a series of brutal escapades, including a fatal burglary, Alex is imprisoned for murder. He undergoes the Ludovico Technique, a controversial aversion therapy that conditions him to associate violence with nausea, ultimately stripping him of his free will and love for classical music, particularly Beethoven.

Upon release, Alex finds himself homeless and targeted for revenge by his past victims, including the scholar he assaulted. He is beaten by former gang members turned policemen and later encounters F. Alexander, the writer whose wife was a victim of his gang. Alexander seeks to use Alex as a symbol against state brutality but eventually realizes Alex's identity. After a failed suicide attempt, Alex is courted by government officials eager to improve their image. 

In the end, Alex, now with a new gang, reflects on his violent past and contemplates a future with a family, pondering the possibility of his son becoming a delinquent like him. The novel explores themes of free will, the nature of violence, and the impact of societal conditioning.

In a near-future England, Alex, a teenage sociopath and leader of a gang called "droogs," engages in extreme violence and crime with his friends. They partake in "ultra-violence," including robbery and assault, while consuming drug-laced milk at the Korova Milkbar. After committing murder during a burglary, Alex is imprisoned and subjected to the Ludovico Technique, a controversial aversion therapy that conditions him to associate violence with nausea, stripping him of his free will and love for classical music.

Upon his release, Alex faces homelessness and revenge from his past victims, including a scholar he assaulted. He is beaten by former gang members who are now policemen and encounters F. Alexander, a writer whose wife was victimized by Alex's gang. Alexander initially seeks to use Alex as a symbol against state brutality but soon realizes his identity. After a failed suicide attempt, Alex is approached by government officials looking to improve their image.

Ultimately, Alex, now with a new gang, reflects on his violent past and considers a future with a family, worrying about the possibility of his son becoming a delinquent like him. The novel explores themes of free will, violence, and societal conditioning, while also hinting at the dangers of artificial intelligence and the manipulation of human society through controlled information.

After being imprisoned, he undergoes the Ludovico Technique, an aversion therapy that conditions him to associate violence with nausea, effectively stripping him of free will and his love for classical music.

Upon his release, Alex faces homelessness and retaliation from his past victims, including a scholar and former gang members turned policemen. He encounters F. Alexander, a writer whose wife was harmed by Alex's gang, who initially seeks to use Alex as a symbol against state brutality but soon recognizes him. After a failed suicide attempt, Alex is approached by government officials aiming to improve their image.

Eventually, Alex forms a new gang and reflects on his violent past, contemplating a future with a family and fearing his son might follow in his delinquent footsteps. The novel delves into themes of free will, violence, societal conditioning, and the risks of artificial intelligence and information manipulation.

After Alex's fellow cellmates blame him for beating a troublesome cellmate to death, he agrees to undergo an experimental behaviour-modification treatment called the Ludovico Technique. The technique is a form of aversion therapy in which Alex receives an injection that makes him feel sick while watching graphically violent films, eventually conditioning him to suffer crippling bouts of nausea at the mere thought of violence. As an unintended consequence, the soundtrack to one of the films—Beethoven's Fifth Symphony—renders Alex unable to listen to his beloved classical music. The effectiveness of the technique is demonstrated to a group of VIPs, who watch as Alex collapses before a walloping bully, and abases himself before a scantily-clad young woman whose presence has aroused his predatory sexual inclinations. Though the prison chaplain accuses the state of stripping Alex of free will, the government officials on the scene are pleased with the results and Alex is released into society. Since his parents are now renting his room to a lodger, Alex wanders the streets and enters a public library where he hopes to learn a painless way to commit suicide. There, he accidentally encounters the old scholar he assaulted earlier in the book, who, keen on revenge, beats Alex with the help of his friends. The policemen who come to Alex's rescue turn out to be none other than Dim and former gang rival Billyboy. The two policemen take Alex outside of town and beat him up. Dazed and bloodied, Alex collapses at the door of an isolated cottage, realizing too late that it is the house he and his droogs invaded in the first half of the story. Because the gang wore masks during the assault, the writer does not recognize Alex. The writer, whose name is revealed as F. Alexander, shelters Alex and questions him about the conditioning. During this sequence, it is revealed that Mrs. Alexander died from the injuries inflicted during the gang-rape, and her husband has decided to continue living "where her fragrant memory persists" despite the horrid memories. Alexander, a critic of the government, hopes to use Alex as a symbol of state brutality and thereby prevent the incumbent government from being re-elected. Eventually, he begins to realize Alex's role in the happenings of the night two years ago. One of Alexander's radical associates manages to extract a confession from Alex after removing him from F. Alexander's home and then locks him in a flatblock near his former home. Alex is then subjected to a relentless barrage of classical music, prompting him to attempt suicide by leaping from a high window. Alex wakes up in hospital, where he is courted by government officials anxious to counter the bad publicity created by his suicide attempt. With Alexander safely packed off to a mental institution, Alex is offered a well-paying job if he agrees to side with the government. As photographers snap pictures, Alex daydreams of orgiastic violence and realizes the Ludovico conditioning has been reversed: "I was cured all right." In the final chapter, Alex has a new trio of droogs, but he finds he is beginning to outgrow his taste for violence. A chance encounter with Pete, now married and settled down, inspires Alex to seek a wife and family of his own. He contemplates the likelihood of his future son being a delinquent as he was, a prospect Alex views fatalistically.

In a near-future England, Alex, a teenage sociopath and leader of a gang known as "droogs," engages in extreme acts of violence and crime with his friends Dim, Georgie, and Pete. They indulge in "ultra-violence," including assaults, robbery, and rape, while consuming drug-laced milk at their hangout, the Korova Milkbar. After a series of brutal escapades, including a fatal burglary, Alex is imprisoned for murder. He undergoes the Ludovico Technique, a controversial aversion therapy that conditions him to associate violence with nausea, ultimately stripping him of his free will and love for classical music, particularly Beethoven.

Upon release, Alex finds himself homeless and targeted for revenge by his past victims, including the scholar he assaulted. He is beaten by former gang members turned policemen and later encounters F. Alexander, the writer whose wife was a victim of his gang. Alexander seeks to use Alex as a symbol against state brutality but eventually realizes Alex's identity. After a failed suicide attempt, Alex is courted by government officials eager to improve their image. 

In the end, Alex, now with a new gang, reflects on his violent past and contemplates a future with a family, pondering the possibility of his son becoming a delinquent like him. The novel explores themes of free will, the nature of violence, and the impact of societal conditioning.

In a near-future England, Alex, a teenage sociopath and leader of a gang called "droogs," indulges in extreme violence and crime, including robbery and assault, while consuming drug-laced milk. After committing murder during a burglary, he is imprisoned and subjected to the Ludovico Technique, an aversion therapy that conditions him to associate violence with nausea, effectively stripping him of free will and his love for classical music.

Upon his release, Alex faces homelessness and retaliation from his past victims, including a scholar and former gang members who are now policemen. He encounters F. Alexander, a writer whose wife was a victim of his gang, who initially seeks to use Alex as a symbol against state brutality but later recognizes him. After a failed suicide attempt, Alex is approached by government officials looking to enhance their image.

Ultimately, Alex, now part of a new gang, reflects on his violent past and considers a future with a family, pondering the possibility of his son becoming a delinquent like him. The novel delves into themes of free will, the nature of violence, and societal conditioning.
